text: Hello everybody this is Lino Coria and I promise you some code here is here's the code I am going
to show you two demos the first one is illustrating the set demo sorry the set interface and we're
going to use the classes hash set and tree set and the second demo is going to be about map
and we're going to be using hash map and tree map so let's start with with set so as I said
this demo here is going to demonstrate the use of hash set and tree set now we first create an array
of integers on line 14 and you're going to see this and it's not an int right it says integer with a
capital I why are we writing integer with a capital I well java collections can only store objects and
it cannot store primitive types so it cannot you know it cannot store int so we have something
called a wrapper and essentially this is going to be what we're going to use when we try to store
integers into a collection so just keep that in mind right so for all purposes these are integers
and so we have here some numbers 42 17 89 3 56 17 23 there's no reason behind the order but you can
you can see that 17 shows up here and also shows up here so it is repeated if we were storing this
on a list this would be no issue we could store repeats but remember that a set only stores repeat
numbers so first we're going to do the hash set demo remember the hash set is really fast but the the
the numbers are going to be stored unordered right and we just print hash set demo then we say that the
hash set it's a set of integers remember the wrapper here but we're going to implement it with the hash set
class here we are using a for each loop or an enhance for loop and remember this is how we read it we say for each
num in numbers and what we're going to do is we're going to be adding each number into our empty hash set
that we have here empty and here we're just printing adding the number right now however this is only if
it is successful but if it's a duplicate we're going to ignore the duplicate this is what we're doing in
this for each for loop and then we just print the contents you're going to see that they're not going
to be in any particular order and then we're going to check if it contains number 17.
we just use this method contains so we says hash it dot contains 17 and it's going to return true
if if it is there right now this is the tree set demo part and so we create an empty tree set right it's a
it's a set of integers and we call it tree set and again we have this enhanced for loop for each num in
numbers we just add it but in this case when we print it because we know this is a tree set is going
to be always sorted and so let's run it and let's see if what i told you is true and so we run it here
and let's see what happens so this is the part of the hash set demo we add 42 success 17 success 89
success i'm going to show you here the numbers that we have in the array right so 89 success 3 success 56
success 17 it's a duplicate it's going to be ignored 23 success and now when we print the contents of the
hash set it is in this order that you know makes no sense to us uh 17 3 23 56 89 42 no no particular order
right uh we checked if it contains 17 and it's it returns true now when we do the tree set demo we
added them in the same order 42 17 89 etc but when we print the contents because it's a tree set it's order
in the natural order right so it goes from smallest to the largest and again 17 even though we added the
number twice because it's a set it it gets ignored so this is the demo for a set so remember a set is a
collection of values in this case integers and depending on the implementation if we use the hash set class
it's really fast we can retrieve these numbers really fast we can check if the number is there
we can add remove it's really fast but they're offered to us in no particular order like we see here
but if we use the tree set demo it's it's slower but it's always going to be in order and it depends
on our application we might want to to use it okay now i'm going to move to the map demo and it's going
to be very very similar here i'm going to demonstrate the use of hash map and tree map in java and we're going to be
storing student names in their scores and we're going to see the differences so here we have in
this case this is a map first we have this array of arrays right of strings and so we have someone's name
and someone's grade and so you will see that in this case the names of the students are the keys because
they could have repeated grades right let's say charlie and bob could both have an 85 so this value
can be the same but the keys which are the names of the students are going to be unique of course this
is just an example it's possible sometimes that when you have students students have the same first name
so that's why we have student id and and other things that are unique to the students but right now
let's assume that names are unique so the hash map again this is fast but comes in no order
we create a map and the map has the string is going to be the key again the name of the students and then
we want integers because right now we have the grades as strings but actually if we want to do any math
with them i think it makes more sense to have them as integers so we have this integer wrapper right and
we create this empty hash map we go again with our uh with our for each our enhanced for loop for each
student in students and the and we use this method put right and so we put the student's name and then we
parse an integer so we convert the string into an integer and we enter it here and so now we have this key
value pairs and we can print what the the hash map contents we can also search for a particular student
for instance we want to get alice's score we have our key alice and we're going to get the store the score
we're going to check bob right is bob there and so we give the key bob and then it tells us if it contains
that key or not we can also update a score so here we can see that charlie if we go back and look at
charlie charlie had an 85 i don't know what happened but charlie now has a 90 so we update it and we can
print again after update and get some information we're going to run it in a little bit now let's see
what we have for the tree map demo for the tree map demo again we start with a with an empty tree map
we say tree map is uh you know it's a map with a key that is a string and a value that is an integer
same enhanced for loop here and we print it now the key difference here is that when we
print it it's going to be the hash map is not going to have the keys in any order but the tree map is going
to have the keys in alphabetical order so let me just run this and here we go for the hash map demo we
have the contents bob equals 78 eve 88 alice 92 charlie 85 david 92 i'm going to go to the original values
that we have here so you can see they they are the same and it is printed in no particular order
right the keys are not really the keys in the order in which we added them they're just there if you
want to retrieve alice's score we get a 92 which is correct if we want to check if bob is there as a
key it returns true and then remember that we changed charlie's grade it is um it is here we gave charlie a
90 and so now we print again and it's the same order that we had here right even though we don't know how
how it was decided uh the same order here here and we have this here but the big difference is that
charlie's grade hardly charlie's score has changed now the tree map demo already has all the keys in
order alice bob charlie david eve right and so when we print just the keys right we have the hash map we
cannot really understand how this was how the order was uh considered here but if we look at the keys
that we have for the tree map we have alphabetical order so so now you know this is how things work
again the hash map is faster but the keys are not stored in order whereas the tree map is going to be
slower depending on how long the the map is right but it's going to return every key is going to be in
order so depends on on your needs and well now you have seen some examples of uh the set interface with
with hash set and with tree set and you have seen an example of map with with the classes hash map and the
class and the class hash map and the class tree map okay i hope this you found this useful thank you for
watching i'm lino korya
